title.narrative: AUC: 2016-2018 Capacity Development Program ICBC, Pillar V
AUC: 2016-2018 Capacity Development Program ICBC, Pillar V

description.narrative:
Afrikanska unionen (AU) är Afrikas främsta politiska organisation och består av femtiofyra medlemsstater från den afrikanska kontinenten. AU initierar och utvecklar panafrikansk politik och ansvarar för att artikulera gemensamma afrikanska intressen i världspolitiken. Idag spelar AU en allt starkare roll för utveckling, samarbete och integration i Afrika.
Denna insats avser stöd till AU- kommissionens (AUC) institutionsutvecklingsprogram (Institutions, Capacity Building and Communications Programme 2014-2017) för åren 2016, 2017 och 2018. 2018 kommer att vara ett överbryggande år inför nya strategiperiod 2019-2023. Programmet inriktas på att främja organisatoriska förändringar och stärka den institutionella kapaciteten i AUC genom att åtgärder för att förbättra sina resultat och den operativa effektiviteten kring ekonomi, HR, administration och institutionellt ledarskap. De sista två åren av programmet kommer också att innefatta en stark kommunikations komponent för att göra AU, AUC och dess mandat mer kända och förstådda på kontinenten.
Stöd till denna insats kanaliseras genom ett samfinansieringsavtal tillsammans med flera andra givare. Förstärkning av den institutionella kapaciteten hos AUC är avgörande för att göra det möjligt för Kommissionen att genomföra sitt uppdrag. Interventionen är av mycket hög relevans för både Sveriges och AUC:s strategiska prioriteringar samt för andra likasinnade partner, liksom Afrikanska Unionens medlemsstater.

The AU and the RECs play a key role in strengthening regional integration and cooperation in Africa as also identified in the Swedish Regional Development Cooperation Strategy with Sub-Saharan Africa (2016-2021). Acknowledging the varying degree of the operationality and institutional capacity of the regional organizations, the strategy envisages that Swedish support to the AU and the RECs should contribute to strengthening the communities’ institutional capacity to carry out their mandates and implement agreed programmes and commitments. Improved capacity in these terms will not only contribute to increased credibility vis-à-vis the citizens of member states, but is also a prerequisite for more effective cooperation between the AU, the RECs and their member states, as well as with donors.
The AUC Institutions, Capacity Building and Communications Pillar will focus on strengthening the institutional capacity of the African Union Commission and strengthening the relationships with AU Organs, RECs and Strategic partners. This program will endow the AUC with the necessary institutional capacity and capability to take on its mandate and to enhance its program delivery.

sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Progress has been made on all fronts of this program and the Kagame reform agenda may have added to the political commitment to bring about someof these much-needed improvements in the internal control environment.
During 2016, a number of staff rules and regulations have been updated and put in place, including anti-corruption, anti-harrassment, code of ethics, etc and a number of administrative procedures have been standardised, including payroll, travel, payments, accounting, etc. These are very welcome.
The Data Center was also launched during the year, providing greater storage capacity, enhanced security and faster access to tools, systems and data. The launch of a new Procurement Manual was also a big achievement.
Full IPSAS compliance is one of the largest hurdles the Commission still needs to fully overcome. It is an ongoing process and progress is being made.
A PME system has been developed during the year, in line with Agenda 2063. RBM has always been a weakness within the Commission and numerous attempts have been made to improve it. Connecting it to Agenda 2063 will not make things easier and implementation will take place during 2017. It also remains to be seen if it will be given priority amongst the long list of priorities of the new Commission.
A new Commission came on board in 2017. They seem to be very committed, but expecations are also very high and the list of priorities long. 2017 will hopefully reveal what is possible.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
